details.description: Pioneered the creation of R's \textbf{1st} all-in-one visualization and analysis package for openly available soccer data.

\textbf{Authored 9} functions while working with other contributors, as an open source project, to co-author 5 functions. Functions are compatible with \textbf{JSON data and specific APIs} while also supporting the use of \textbf{webscraped data}.
Coded function use cases range from \textbf{data wrangling}, \textbf{visualization}, and implementation of complicated analysis such as \textbf{Markov chain analysis}

Contributor to the official landing page with Github Pages that experiences an average of \textbf{800}+ views and \textbf{100}+ unique vistors per week. Initial release and updates invite upwards of \textbf{1000}+ views on the package.

Recognized by various open source projects and package aggregators such as \textbf{PySport} and \textbf{LibHunt} while being one of the \textbf{most in-demand packages} in the soccer analytics community.
\textbf{Led the back-end} to create a responsive schedule creator that allowed multiple users to create tasks, rank them, and place them on a dynamic calendar in real-time.
Constructed a server for the front-end that successfully connected the user's data to a \textbf{PostgreSQL database}.
\textbf{Used MikroOrm in TypeScript} to be able to handle data in an object-orientated manner. Scheduler was able to handle upwards of \textbf{10} students at the same time.

\textbf{Led team of 4} to \textbf{2nd place finish} by creating an \textbf{artificial intelligence model} that allowed teachers and advisors to identify students at risk and deliver a personalized diagnosis for them.
Utilized \textbf{UTD's novel s(CASP)} model to \textbf{construct logic} for risk identification and connecting risk identification component to student recommendation system.
Created a portable web application in \textbf{ShinyR} to showcase analysis results on publicly available soccer data.

Created novel new models such as the \textbf{Clinical Finishing Model} and used \textbf{unsupervised machine learning techniques} along with \textbf{dimension reduction} to define a \textbf{similarity index}.
Using \textbf{factoextra} and performed a \textbf{K-Means Clustering} on self-collected data on soccer players.
